Award.AwardTitle: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Laser Sintering of Nanolayered Carbon Nanotube Paper for Functionally Gradient Ceramic Nanocomposites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to study the processing-structure-property relationship of functionally gradient nanolayered ceramic nanocomposite coating fabricated through a new paper making - laser sintering process, and test the hypothesis that the addition of carbon nanotubes can yield significant enhancement in mechanical properties of the ceramic coatings. It is a high-risk but high-payoff project because the new process is radically different from traditional approaches to make ceramic nanocomposite coating. This project's approach involves: 1) paper making process to manufacture nanolayered carbon nanotube paper consisting of both ceramic nanoparticles and carbon nanotubes, 2) laser sintering of the paper layer by layer to fabricate the functionally gradient coating, and 3) characterization of microstructures and mechanical properties of the fabricated nanocomposite coating. In the paper making - laser sintering process, good dispersion and controlled alignment of carbon nanotubes will be achieved in a suspension under an electric field. A suitable functionally gradient multilayered coating can be realized by laser sintering of the paper layer by layer, with varied and controlled compositions in each layer. The developed functionally gradient coating can potentially decrease the possibility of cracks and delamination at the coating-substrate interface significantly. Specifically, the grant will be used to demonstrate whether the addition of the carbon nanotubes will result in improved fracture toughness of the coating.
This research will have a major impact on ceramic nanocomposite coating through advancing manufacturing science of ceramic nanocomposite coating and better understanding its structure-property relationship. The project will have broad potential impacts on aerospace, automotive, biomedical, and many other areas, where ceramic coatings play a key role. Some examples include the thermal barrier coatings in gas turbine engines, and the wear or corrosion resistance coatings needed in numerous medical implants and mechanical components.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has studied the fabrication of carbon nanotube (CNT) – ceramic nanocomposites through laser sintering of CNTs and ceramic powders. The sintered materials have been characterized using scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and Raman spectroscopy, etc. The sintered material mechanical properties (e.g., fracture toughness) have also been measured. 

 

Under the corresponding studied conditions, for laser sintering of the mixtures of CNTs and ceramic powers, it has been found that CNTs can still be clearly observed in the scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of laser-sintered nanocomposites, and the fracture toughness of laser-sintered CNT-ceramic nanocomposites is obviously higher than that for the ceramic material obtained by laser sintering of ceramic powders without CNTs. The results support the hypothesis that CNTs may increase the fracture toughness of laser-sintered ceramic under suitable conditions.   On the other hand, it has also been found that it is difficult to get good mechanical properties through laser sintering if the CNT weight percentage is not sufficiently low.


Intellectual Merit:

Through the research work in this project, the understanding
of ceramic nanocomposites fabrication by laser sintering, the composite
structure and mechanical properties, has been enhanced.


Broader Impact:

Due to their unique properties, numerous industrial applications may need ceramic materials (for example, as wear or corrosion resistant surface coatings on many mechanical components or parts).  This work has studied the carbon nanotube – ceramic nanocomposite fabrication through laser sintering. It has provided useful information for the manufacturing of ceramic materials with enhanced mechanical properties, and hence may benefit many related areas that need ceramic materials with good mechanical properties.


Last Modified: 10/31/2013
Modified by: Benxin Wu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project has studied the fabrication of carbon nanotube (CNT) – ceramic nanocomposites through laser sintering of CNTs and ceramic powders. The sintered materials have been characterized using scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and Raman spectroscopy, etc. The sintered material mechanical properties (e.g., fracture toughness) have also been measured. Under the corresponding studied conditions, for laser sintering of the mixtures of CNTs and ceramic powers, it has been found that CNTs can still be clearly observed in the scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of laser-sintered nanocomposites, and the fracture toughness of laser-sintered CNT-ceramic nanocomposites is obviously higher than that for the ceramic material obtained by laser sintering of ceramic powders without CNTs. The results support the hypothesis that CNTs may increase the fracture toughness of laser-sintered ceramic under suitable conditions. On the other hand, it has also been found that it is difficult to get good mechanical properties through laser sintering if the CNT weight percentage is not sufficiently low. Intellectual Merit: Through the research work in this project, the understanding of ceramic nanocomposites fabrication by laser sintering, the composite structure and mechanical properties, has been enhanced. Broader Impact: Due to their unique properties, numerous industrial applications may need ceramic materials (for example, as wear or corrosion resistant surface coatings on many mechanical components or parts). This work has studied the carbon nanotube – ceramic nanocomposite fabrication through laser sintering. It has provided useful information for the manufacturing of ceramic materials with enhanced mechanical properties, and hence may benefit many related areas that need ceramic materials with good mechanical properties.
